item.title: About me
item.description: I grew up in a small paper mill town on the coast of Maine. When I was 16, one of the fossil fuel majors proposed opening a coal-fired power plant in my town. It was my first experience of big companies try to take advantage of small communities. My father took me along to local town council and planning board meetings, so I got to see first-hand how the proposed coal plant generated conflicts in the town and how the fight to prevent it was finally won.

item.title: Critical Minerals and Social Conflict: Interactive Map and Data Dashboard
item.description:
In numbers: Critical mineral production, ownership, and social unrest

I worked closely with a colleague develop this data dashboard and interactive map showing incidents of social unrest related to and in proximity to transition mineral mines.

This project was delivered at pace. I coordinated relationships with public and private data providers, wireframed the project and hired an interactive developer, and ensured that the data was processed correctly before being fed into the dashboard and map.
